docs.title: Civic Tech Community Organizer Toolkit
docs.text: Version: 1.0 Date: August 30, 2017 Updated by: Isha Nepal and Emily Kuzan

docs.title: About This Toolkit
docs.text:
Civic tech communities are being established in cities around the world. These volunteer-run hubs foster innovation and networking between public servants, technology professionals, designers, and civic activists. At the heart of these communities is the weekly “hacknight.”

This toolkit provides key tips to help you establish and run successful hacknights. It is a collaborative, living document created by Isha Nepal and Emily Kuzan on behalf of Code for Canada, with contributions from organizers in the global civic tech community.

docs.text:

docs.title: About Civic Tech Community Groups
docs.text: The main goal of civic tech groups is to bring together individuals from diverse backgrounds to solve civic challenges using technology and design, typically through weekly “hacknights.”

docs.title: Common Characteristics of Civic Tech Hacknights
docs.text:
• Regular Meetings: Weekly, biweekly, or monthly gatherings lasting 2.5-3 hours.
  • Structured Agenda: Introductions, optional presentations, and project hacking.
  • Inclusivity: Civic Tech 101 sessions to onboard new members.

docs.title: Key Ingredients for a Successful Hacknight
docs.text:
1. Environment: Create a collaborative and welcoming space.
  2. Attendance: Encourage diverse participation for cross-sector collaboration.
  3. Projects: Provide at least two project options to engage participants.
  4. Adaptability: Tailor hacknights to your community's specific needs.

docs.title: How to Start a Civic Tech Community Group
1. Find Co-Founders
docs.text:
• Identify passionate individuals to share responsibilities.
  • Reach out to colleagues or your network to build a founding team.

docs.title: 2. Organize a Trial Hacknight
docs.text:
• Test the concept with a small, prototype event.
  • Promote through social media or platforms like Meetup.com.
  • Seed the event with at least one project idea.

docs.title: How to Organize a Civic Tech Hacknight
1. Find a Venue
docs.text:
• Look for accessible locations like tech firms, shared workspaces, libraries, or community centers.
  • Ensure basic amenities like Wi-Fi, projectors, and workspaces.

docs.title: 2. Find Speakers (Optional)
docs.text:
• Speakers can provide insights and attract attendees.
  • Rotate speakers monthly or invite individuals with relevant expertise.

docs.title: 3. Send Invitations
docs.text:
• Invite technologists, designers, civil servants, and community activists.
  • Use email templates or social media to publicize the event.

docs.title: How to Keep Your Hacknights Running Smoothly
docs.text:
• Use tools like Meetup.com, Slack, and GitHub to stay organized.
  • Rotate organizers to prevent burnout.
  • Maintain clear roles with templates for agendas, speaker scheduling, and more.

docs.title: Templates You Can Adapt
docs.text:
These templates can be customized for your community:

  • Agenda and MC Talking Points
  • Civic Tech 101 Slides
  • Code of Conduct
  • Hacknight Roles
  • Speaker Scheduling

docs.title: How do civic tech hacknights differ from other hacknights?
docs.text: Civic tech hacknights include a civic-focused element, solving public interest issues in addition to technical challenges.

docs.title: How can I connect local governments and activists?
docs.text: Collaboration starts with outreach and communication. Use platforms like Slack and Meetup to engage both groups.

docs.text:
We welcome feedback and suggestions to improve this toolkit. Share your ideas or request new content by commenting directly or reaching out to the authors.

This document is a living resource and will evolve with contributions from the global civic tech community.

docs.title: What is CivicTechWR?
docs.text: CivicTechWR is a community group focused on solving local issues through design and technology.

docs.title: How can I get involved?
docs.text: You can get involved by attending our meetups, joining our Slack, and contributing to our projects on GitHub. Check the Get Involved section for more details.

docs.title: When and where are the meetups?
docs.text: Our meetups are usually scheduled regularly. You can find the latest schedule and venue details on our Meetup page.

docs.title: How can I join the Slack community?
docs.text: Join our Slack community by following this invite link.

docs.title: What kind of projects does CivicTechWR work on?
docs.text: We work on a variety of projects that aim to address local community issues using technology and design. Check our GitHub repository to see our current and past projects.

docs.title: How can I contribute to a project?
docs.text: You can contribute by checking out our projects on GitHub and following the contribution guidelines provided in each project repository.

docs.title: Who can join CivicTechWR?
docs.text: Anyone with an interest in using technology and design to solve community issues is welcome to join.

docs.title: Do I need any specific skills to join?
docs.text: No specific skills are required. We welcome people with diverse backgrounds and skill sets.

docs.title: How can I stay updated on CivicTechWR activities?
docs.text: You can stay updated by joining our Meetup group, our Slack community, and following our GitHub repository.

docs.title: Where can I find more information?
docs.text: For more detailed information, visit our website.

docs.text: Welcome to the guidelines section.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: To ensure clear, respectful, and effective communication within the CivicTechWR community.

docs.title: General Principles
docs.text:
• Be respectful and considerate.
  • Listen actively and respond thoughtfully.
  • Use clear and concise language.

docs.title: Communication Channels
docs.text:
• Slack: For real-time communication and collaboration.
  • Email: For formal and detailed communication.
  • GitHub: For project-related discussions and issues.
  • Meetup.com: For event announcements, RSVPs, and community updates.

docs.title: Conflict Resolution
docs.text:
• Address conflicts promptly and respectfully.
  • Seek to understand different perspectives.
  • Escalate to organizers if necessary.

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text:
• Fork the repository.
  • Create a new branch for your work.
  • Make your changes.
  • Submit a pull request for review.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Write clear and concise commit messages.
  • Follow the coding standards and style guide.
  • Test your changes thoroughly before submitting.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: Ensure your contributions align with our Code of Conduct.

docs.title: policies
docs.text: Welcome to the policies section.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: At Civic Tech Waterloo, we are committed to fostering a respectful and inclusive environment for all participants, regardless. We do not tolerate harassment or discrimination of any kind, including verbal abuse, intimidation, or bias based on gender, race, religion, sexual orientation, or any other personal characteristic.

docs.title: Expected Behavior
docs.text:
• Be respectful and considerate of others.
  • Communicate openly and listen to others.
  • Appreciate different perspectives and experiences.
  • Engage in constructive discussions.

docs.title: Unacceptable Behavior
docs.text:
• Harassment, discrimination, or intimidation.
  • Verbal abuse or personal attacks.
  • Disruptive behavior that hinders the participation of others.
  • Inappropriate physical contact or unwelcome sexual attention.

docs.title: Reporting and Enforcement
docs.text:
If something or someone is making you feel uncomfortable, please reach out to one of our organizers so we can address this.

  • Participants asked to stop any harassing behavior must comply immediately.
  • Violators may be sanctioned or asked to leave at the organizers' discretion.

tl;dr: Be a nice human.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: To promote an inclusive environment that values diversity and ensures equal opportunities for all participants.

docs.title: Commitment
docs.text: Civic Tech Waterloo is committed to fostering a culture where diversity is celebrated, and all members feel welcomed and respected regardless of gender, race, ethnicity, religion, age, sexual orientation, disability, or socioeconomic status.

docs.title: Practices
docs.text:
• Actively recruit and support diverse members.
  • Ensure accessible and inclusive events and meetings.
  • Encourage diverse perspectives in decision-making.

docs.title: Reporting
docs.text: Members are encouraged to report any incidents of discrimination or harassment to the organizers. All reports will be handled confidentially and promptly.

docs.title: Review
docs.text:
This policy will be reviewed annually to ensure it remains effective and relevant.

tl;dr: We value and respect diversity and inclusion.

Discussion and Pitches
docs.text: • We had a big discussion about rallying behind a single project vs fostering multiple projects. Outcome so far is to keep exploring and experimenting.

docs.title: Radical Transparency
docs.text:
• David proposed developing a platform that leverages AI to review and summarize city council meetings.
  • This platform can help people understand what took place in these meetings.
  • It can also be a valuable resource during election time, allowing voters to learn where candidates stand on the issues they care about most.
  • The ability to search within the platform would greatly help people stay informed.
  • This idea can also be adapted to other formats, such as school board meetings.
